articles.title: Docker Fixes Critical Ask Gordon AI Flaw Allowing Code Execution via Image Metadata
articles.summary: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a now-patched security flaw impacting Ask Gordon, an artificial intelligence (AI) assistant built into Docker Desktop and the Docker Command-Line Interface (CLI), that could be exploited to execute code and exfiltrate sensitive data. The critical vulnerability has been codenamed DockerDash by cybersecurity company Noma Labs. It was addressed by

articles.title: [Webinar] The Smarter SOC Blueprint: Learn What to Build, Buy, and Automate
articles.summary: Most security teams today are buried under tools. Too many dashboards. Too much noise. Not enough real progress. Every vendor promises “complete coverage” or “AI-powered automation,” but inside most SOCs, teams are still overwhelmed, stretched thin, and unsure which tools are truly pulling their weight. The result? Bloated stacks, missed signals, and mounting pressure to do more with less. This

articles.title: Hackers Exploit Metro4Shell RCE Flaw in React Native CLI npm Package
articles.summary: Threat actors have been observed exploiting a critical security flaw impacting the Metro Development Server in the popular "@react-native-community/cli" npm package. Cybersecurity company VulnCheck said it first observed exploitation of CVE-2025-11953 (aka Metro4Shell) on December 21, 2025. With a CVSS score of 9.8, the vulnerability allows remote unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary

articles.title: When Cloud Outages Ripple Across the Internet
articles.summary: Recent major cloud service outages have been hard to miss. High-profile incidents affecting providers such as AWS, Azure, and Cloudflare have disrupted large parts of the internet, taking down websites and services that many other systems depend on. The resulting ripple effects have halted applications and workflows that many organizations rely on every day. For consumers, these outages are

articles.title: APT28 Uses Microsoft Office CVE-2026-21509 in Espionage-Focused Malware Attacks
articles.summary: The Russia-linked state-sponsored threat actor known as APT28 (aka UAC-0001) has been attributed to attacks exploiting a newly disclosed security flaw in Microsoft Office as part of a campaign codenamed Operation Neusploit. Zscaler ThreatLabz said it observed the hacking group weaponizing the shortcoming on January 29, 2026, in attacks targeting users in Ukraine, Slovakia, and Romania, three

articles.title: Mozilla Adds One-Click Option to Disable Generative AI Features in Firefox
articles.summary: Mozilla on Monday announced a new controls section in its Firefox desktop browser settings that allows users to completely turn off generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) features. "It provides a single place to block current and future generative AI features in Firefox," Ajit Varma, head of Firefox, said. "You can also review and manage individual AI features if you choose to use them. This

articles.title: Notepad++ Hosting Breach Attributed to China-Linked Lotus Blossom Hacking Group
articles.summary: A China-linked threat actor known as Lotus Blossom has been attributed with medium confidence to the recently discovered compromise of the infrastructure hosting Notepad++. The attack enabled the state-sponsored hacking group to deliver a previously undocumented backdoor codenamed Chrysalis to users of the open-source editor, according to new findings from Rapid7. The development comes shortly

articles.title: Researchers Find 341 Malicious ClawHub Skills Stealing Data from OpenClaw Users
articles.summary: A security audit of 2,857 skills on ClawHub has found 341 malicious skills across multiple campaigns, according to new findings from Koi Security, exposing users to new supply chain risks. ClawHub is a marketplace designed to make it easy for OpenClaw users to find and install third-party skills. It's an extension to the OpenClaw project, a self-hosted artificial intelligence (AI) assistant

articles.title: Kimwolf Botnet Lurking in Corporate, Govt. Networks
articles.summary: A new Internet-of-Things botnet called Kimwolf has spread to more than 2 million devices, forcing infected systems to participate in massive distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and to relay other malicious and abusive Internet traffic. Kimwolf's ability to scan the local networks of compromised systems for other IoT devices to infect makes it a sobering threat to organizations, and new research reveals Kimwolf is surprisingly prevalent in government and corporate networks.

articles.title: Patch Tuesday, January 2026 Edition
articles.summary: Microsoft today issued patches to plug at least 113 security holes in its various Windows operating systems and supported software. Eight of the vulnerabilities earned Microsoft's most-dire "critical" rating, and the company warns that attackers are already exploiting one of the bugs fixed today.

articles.title: Who Benefited from the Aisuru and Kimwolf Botnets?
articles.summary: Our first story of 2026 revealed how a destructive new botnet called Kimwolf rapidly grew to infect more than two million devices by mass-compromising a vast number of unofficial Android TV streaming boxes. Today, we'll dig through digital clues left behind by the hackers, network operators, and cybercrime services that appear to have benefitted from Kimwolf's spread.

articles.title: The Kimwolf Botnet is Stalking Your Local Network
articles.summary: The story you are reading is a series of scoops nestled inside a far more urgent Internet-wide security advisory. The vulnerability at issue has been exploited for months already, and it's time for a broader awareness of the threat. The short version is that everything you thought you knew about the security of the internal network behind your Internet router probably is now dangerously out of date.

articles.title: Happy 16th Birthday, KrebsOnSecurity.com!
articles.summary: KrebsOnSecurity.com celebrates its 16th anniversary today! A huge "thank you" to all of our readers -- newcomers, long-timers and drive-by critics alike. Your engagement this past year here has been tremendous and truly a salve on a handful of dark days. Happily, comeuppance was a strong theme running through our coverage in 2025, with a primary focus on entities that enabled complex and globally-dispersed cybercrime services.

articles.title: Dismantling Defenses: Trump 2.0 Cyber Year in Review
articles.summary: The Trump administration has pursued a staggering range of policy pivots this past year that threaten to weaken the nation’s ability and willingness to address a broad spectrum of technology challenges, from cybersecurity and privacy to countering disinformation, fraud and corruption. These shifts, along with the president’s efforts to restrict free speech and freedom of the press, have come at such a rapid clip that many readers probably aren’t even aware of them all.

articles.title: Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content
articles.summary: Direct navigation -- the act of visiting a website by manually typing a domain name in a web browser -- has never been riskier: A new study finds the vast majority of "parked" domains -- mostly expired or dormant domain names, or common misspellings of popular websites -- are now configured to redirect visitors to sites that foist scams and malware.

articles.title: Microsoft Patch Tuesday, December 2025 Edition
articles.summary: Microsoft today pushed updates to fix at least 56 security flaws in its Windows operating systems and supported software. This final Patch Tuesday of 2025 tackles one zero-day bug that is already being exploited, as well as two publicly disclosed vulnerabilities.

articles.title: Russian Hackers Weaponize Microsoft Office Bug in Just 3 Days
articles.summary: APT28's attacks rely on specially crafted Microsoft Rich Text Format (RTF) documents to kick off a multistage infection chain to deliver malicious payloads.

articles.title: GlassWorm Malware Returns to Shatter Developer Ecosystems
articles.summary: The self-replicating malware has poisoned a fresh set of Open VSX software components, leaving potential downstream victims with infostealer infections.

articles.title: 8-Minute Access: AI Accelerates Breach of AWS Environment
articles.summary: The AI-assisted attack, which started with exposed credentials from public S3 buckets, rapidly achieved administrative privilges.

articles.title: Dark Patterns Undermine Security, One Click at a Time
articles.summary: People trust organizations to do the right thing, but some websites and apps have user interfaces that ultimately lead to inadequate security for users.

articles.title: Attackers Harvest Dropbox Logins Via Fake PDF Lures
articles.summary: A malware-free phishing campaign targets corporate inboxes and asks employees to view "request orders," ultimately leading to Dropbox credential theft.

articles.title: County Pays $600K to Wrongfully Jailed Pen Testers
articles.summary: Iowa police arrested two penetration testers in 2019 for doing their jobs, highlighting the risk to security professionals in red teaming exercises.

articles.title: Chinese Hackers Hijack Notepad++ Updates for 6 Months
articles.summary: State-sponsored threat actors compromised the popular code editor's hosting provider to redirect targeted users to malicious downloads.

articles.title: ShinyHunters Expands Scope of SaaS Extortion Attacks
articles.summary: Following their attacks on Salesforce instances last year, members of the cybercrime group have broadened their targeting and gotten more aggressive with extortion tactics.

articles.title: RADICL Raises $31 Million for vSOC
articles.summary: The company will use the investment to accelerate development of its autonomous virtual security operations center (vSOC). The post RADICL Raises $31 Million for vSOC appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: RapidFort Raises $42M to Automate Software Supply Chain Security
articles.summary: The company will use the latest capital to scale its go-to-market efforts and expand its platform’s capabilities. The post RapidFort Raises $42M to Automate Software Supply Chain Security appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Critical React Native Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild
articles.summary: Albeit mainly considered a theoretical risk, the flaw has been exploited to disable protections and deliver malware. The post Critical React Native Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Vulnerability Allows Hackers to Hijack OpenClaw AI Assistant
articles.summary: OpenClaw (aka Moltbot and Clawdbot) is vulnerable to one-click remote code execution attacks. The post Vulnerability Allows Hackers to Hijack OpenClaw AI Assistant appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Hackers Leak 5.1 Million Panera Bread Records
articles.summary: ShinyHunters has claimed the theft of 14 million records from the US bakery-cafe chain’s systems. The post Hackers Leak 5.1 Million Panera Bread Records appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Russia’s APT28 Rapidly Weaponizes Newly Patched Office Vulnerability
articles.summary: The attacks targeting Europe were analyzed by Ukraine’s CERT-UA and the cybersecurity company Zscaler. The post Russia’s APT28 Rapidly Weaponizes Newly Patched Office Vulnerability appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Kasada Raises $20 Million for Anti-Bot Expansion
articles.summary: The company will invest in market expansion and accelerating product capabilities. The post Kasada Raises $20 Million for Anti-Bot Expansion appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: ShinyHunters-Branded Extortion Activity Expands, Escalates
articles.summary: Hackers rely on evolved vishing and login harvesting to compromise SSO credentials for unauthorized MFA enrollment. The post ShinyHunters-Branded Extortion Activity Expands, Escalates appeared first on SecurityWeek .

articles.title: Student Loan Breach Exposes 2.5M Records
articles.summary: 2.5 million people were affected, in a breach that could spell more trouble down the line.

articles.title: Watering Hole Attacks Push ScanBox Keylogger
articles.summary: Researchers uncover a watering hole attack likely carried out by APT TA423, which attempts to plant the ScanBox JavaScript-based reconnaissance tool.

articles.title: Tentacles of ‘0ktapus’ Threat Group Victimize 130 Firms
articles.summary: Over 130 companies tangled in sprawling phishing campaign that spoofed a multi-factor authentication system.

articles.title: Ransomware Attacks are on the Rise
articles.summary: Lockbit is by far this summer’s most prolific ransomware group, trailed by two offshoots of the Conti group.

articles.title: Cybercriminals Are Selling Access to Chinese Surveillance Cameras
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of cameras have failed to patch a critical, 11-month-old CVE, leaving thousands of organizations exposed.

articles.title: Twitter Whistleblower Complaint: The TL;DR Version
articles.summary: Twitter is blasted for security and privacy lapses by the company’s former head of security who alleges the social media giant’s actions amount to a national security risk.

articles.title: Firewall Bug Under Active Attack Triggers CISA Warning
articles.summary: CISA is warning that Palo Alto Networks’ PAN-OS is under active attack and needs to be patched ASAP.

articles.title: Fake Reservation Links Prey on Weary Travelers
articles.summary: Fake travel reservations are exacting more pain from the travel weary, already dealing with the misery of canceled flights and overbooked hotels.

articles.summary: View CSAF Summary Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to, modify, delete, or destroy information stored on the system where the affected product is installed, or cause a denial-of-service condition on the affected system.
